title-group.article-title: Use of ultra-brief pulse electroconvulsive therapy to treat severe postnatal mood disorder

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To describe the use of ultra-brief electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) in three postnatal women with severe, treatment resistant depression. The indications and evidence for the use of ECT in the treatment of postnatal depression are discussed.

sec.title: Method:
sec.p: We present a case series and review relevant literature.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Three patients with severe episodes of depression postnatally, not responding to medication, presented to a private mother-baby inpatient unit. All three patients had significant suicidal ideation and two underwent involuntary treatment in public hospitals during the course of their presenting illnesses. They were treated with right unilateral ultra-brief ECT and a range of medications. All women began to respond within 3–6 treatments and no significant cognitive side effects were observed.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Our findings suggest that right unilateral ultra-brief ECT is a useful treatment modality for severe and treatment resistant depression in the postnatal period. ECT is a useful option in women who have experienced significant medication side effects, or for those whose severity of illness necessitates rapid symptom resolution. Ultra-brief ECT caused minimal clinically observable side effects, which may assist mothers to resume care of their infants more rapidly.

body.p: Although the use of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) for treatment of severe depression and other mental disorders has been well established,1,2 it still creates controversy.3,4 It is therefore important for clinicians to be aware of the evidence for the use of ECT in special and vulnerable populations.5

For severely depressed postpartum women, ECT has been advocated as an effective treatment option. It is usually used in mothers who are suicidal or infanticidal, or who have a drug-resistant severe depression. It may also be advantageous in breastfeeding mothers who do not want to expose their infants to medication. However, apart from a small study conducted in 1961 that was not blinded and did not use standardised assessments of outcome,6 there is no experimental research examining the efficacy of ECT in a postnatal population.5 There is, however, a widespread belief that puerperal disorders respond particularly well to ECT.7

There is currently no information on the use of the newer ultra-brief form of ECT in postnatal populations. Ultra-brief pulse ECT uses a narrower pulse-width of 0.3 milliseconds, which is postulated to stimulate a smaller band of tissue, minimising stimulation of adjacent, non-targeted brain areas, and thus reducing associated side-effects.8 In view of the lack of data on ultra-brief ECT in postnatal patients, we report this case series of three depressed women.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: Three consecutive patients admitted to a mother-baby ward in a private hospital setting who were diagnosed with severe postnatal depression, and treated with right unilateral ultra-brief ECT were selected for inclusion. All patients underwent physical examination, baseline blood tests and electrocardiogram prior to commencement of ECT. ECT was performed three times per week and each patient was treated until they achieved remission of symptoms.

Treatments were carried out in a dedicated ECT suite in a private psychiatric hospital, using a MECTA spectrum 5000M machine, upgraded to dispense an ultra-brief pulse width. Seizure threshold was only titrated at the first session. At the time of this case series, there was no protocol standardising the dose above seizure threshold being given. Subsequent dosages were determined by the treating clinician. Adequate seizures were defined as greater than or equal to 15 seconds in duration with adequate post-ictal suppression.

Women were administered the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS)9 and the Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale (DASS-21)10 before and after their course of ECT. Side effects (including effects on memory) were assessed at twice weekly clinical interview. No formal testing of cognition was performed.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Patients 1 (aged 40 years) and 2 (37years) had melancholic depression and patient 3 (34 years) was psychotically depressed following an episode of manic psychosis. All three women had severe melancholic depressive symptoms and were significantly suicidal. Patient 3 also had psychotic features. Patient 2 and patient 3 required involuntary treatment in public hospitals during the course of their illnesses.

Patient 2 had significant psychiatric co-morbidities, including post-traumatic stress disorder with onset occurring following a motor vehicle accident. She also had an associated panic disorder with agoraphobia. Her past history included recurrent episodes of treatment resistant major depression dating back to the age of 18 years. Patient 1 had a post-partum psychosis following the birth of her first child. Patient 3 had no past psychiatric history. Both patient 2 and patient 3 had significant family histories. All three patients had received medication before commencing treatment with ECT. Table 1 summarises the medications they took prior to and during their course of ECT.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Apart from potentially serious consequences for the mother herself, severe postnatal depression can have a deleterious impact in numerous other ways. It may jeopardise maternal-infant interactions11 and result in negative perceptions of infant behaviour.12 This may lead to attachment insecurity,13–15 emotional developmental delay13,15 and social difficulties.16,17 Cognitive skills,18 expressive language development19 and attention20 in infants may also be negatively influenced by postnatal depression, and it has also been reported that children of depressed mothers are two to five times more likely to develop long-term behavioural problems,21,22 Child neglect and abuse,19 marital stress resulting in separation or divorce,23,24 and maternal and infant mortality are other potential outcomes. In order to alleviate suffering in mothers and prevent these corollaries of postnatal mood disorder, it is essential to define and validate the treatment options available to postpartum women.

ECT may be a good option for those who cannot wait for the delayed onset of action of drugs, those concerned about medication side effects and those with gross impairments in self-care, cognition, and judgment that threaten safety and well-being.25 In a postpartum population, there is an even greater imperative for a speedy recovery because of the impact of the mother’s illness on her baby. Some mothers may also choose ECT because of concerns about medication in the breast-milk and the potential harm to the infant.

However, use of ECT can be limited by adverse cognitive effects. These include a variable period of disorientation after each treatment, anterograde amnesia and retrograde amnesia. In postpartum women, these side effects may limit a mother’s ability to rapidly resume caring for her infant. The potential loss of memories of one’s infant in their first weeks or months is also a matter that may legitimately concern patients.

Manipulation of the pulse width of the electrical stimulus is a prominent technique currently under examination26 that seeks to minimise adverse effects of ECT. Analysis of cognitive outcomes in patients treated with ultrabrief pulse width has demonstrated significantly less impairment of anterograde and retrograde memory compared to patients receiving standard pulsewidth stimulation, for both RUL and bilateral ECT.

Thus far, clinical research involving ultrabrief pulsewidth in ECT has been limited. The main evidence comes from two double-blind, randomized controlled trials and an effectiveness trial.26–28 There is no experimental research examining the efficacy of ultra-brief ECT in a postnatal population.

Although there is a commonly held belief that puerperal disorders are more sensitive than non-puerperal disorders to ECT, or more sensitive to ECT than other treatments,7 there are no published data clearly confirming this notion. Reed and colleagues7 found that the clinical improvement following ECT was greater in postpartum psychosis compared to non-postpartum psychosis. However, there were a number of methodological difficulties with the study, including reliance on retrospective examination of case notes and use of crude outcome measures.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: The research presented describes a series of only three cases and the results may not be generalisable. Objective symptom measures were not obtained in one patient; however, ongoing review by a senior clinician suggested that this patient was in remission. Formal cognitive testing was not performed. Hence, any conclusions about tolerability need further verification. Patient 1 and patient 2 were commenced on new antidepressants during the course of ECT. These drugs may have had a synergistic impact on the response to ECT but it is unlikely that they were solely responsible for recovery.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Right unilateral ultra-brief ECT is an effective treatment in the postnatal period for mothers suffering from severe mood disorder. The outcomes of this case series support the widely held, but poorly validated, view that this population responds particularly well to ECT. Ultra-brief ECT may have the added benefit of minimal cognitive side-effects, allowing mothers to more rapidly resume caring for their baby. More research is required to validate this approach.
